section.name: What is a .dar file?
section.p: Dalmacon uses a jar file that has the .dar extension to package a workflow application (which possibly consists of multiple class files and jar files) into a single file. This makes it easy to copy/install workflow applications into Dalmacon. A dar file has the following structure:
section.pre: foo.dar +- META-INF | +- MANIFEST.MF +- *.jar +- org | +- acme | +- Foo.class | +- ... ...

subsection.name: MANIFEST.MF
subsection.p: MANIFEST.MF is used in the same way and has the same format as in a jar file. Dalma adds one optiona attribute called Dalma-Main-Class, which points to the fully-qualified class name of a Program-derived class that serves as the entry point of a workflow application. (It's analogous to the Main-Class attribute that points to a class that has the main method.)
When this attribute is not present, Main (a class in the root package) is used.

subsection.name: *.jar
subsection.p: Additional jar files that a workflow application depends on may simply be placed at the top-level. Those jar files are made available to the workflow application classloader.

subsection.name: Class files
subsection.p: Class files can be put into a dar file just like in a jar file, and those class files are also made available to the same workflow application classloader that loads *.jar. (Alternatively, you can choose to package all your code into jar files and have no bare-naked *.class files.)

subsection.name: When to use a dar file?
subsection.p: Use a dar file when you distribute your workflow application.

subsection.name: When NOT to use a dar file?
subsection.p: When you are developing a workflow application, use the "exploded" format (which is a normal directory that has the same file structure as a dar file) to improve the speed of the debug cycle. Creating and extracting a dar file is unnecessary overhead in such a situation.

subsection.name: How to create a dar file?
subsection.p: With Maven, install Maven dalma plugin and use dalma:dar target.
